results.headline: Life in Motion
results.summary_short: There is plenty of sleek, expensive-looking computer animation on display in the fourth edition of “The Animation Show.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Animation Show 4

results.headline: Trying to Pay the Interest on His Debt to Society
results.summary_short: An ingenuous 24-year-old man-child is at the center of John Crowley’s wrenching melodrama “Boy A.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Boy A

results.headline: Cry the High-Minded Hero in Brutal Japanese-Occupied Manchuria
results.summary_short: In keeping with the grandeur of its title, “The Human Condition” is anything but modest in scope and ambition.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Human Condition

results.headline: Paris Hustler Past His Prime Takes Stock
results.summary_short: “Before I Forget” is an unblinking portrait of a complicated, solitary gay man who has outlived his working years.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Before I Forget

results.headline: A Madman Is Loose (and He’s the Good Guy)
results.summary_short: If the insanely inventive and entertaining “Mad Detective” weren’t so weird -- and in Cantonese -- hordes of action geeks would be lining the block to see it.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mad Detective

results.headline: Tales From Divided Berlin, Where Angst Ate the Soul
results.summary_short: In Julian Schnabel’s grimly majestic concert film “Lou Reed’s Berlin,” Mr. Reed wears the deadpan smirk of a Zen master who has endured punishing Buddhist training.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lou Reed's Berlin

results.headline: In Thailand, Two Lovers Among a Tsunami’s Ruins
results.summary_short: Everything is, for a good long while, very nice indeed in “Wonderful Town.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wonderful Town

results.headline: Intrigue on an Ill-Fated Train, Moscow-Bound
results.summary_short: “Transsiberian” is a handsomely remodeled variation of a cherished genre you might call the mystery-train movie.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Transsiberian

results.headline: Showdown in Gotham Town
results.summary_short: Pitched at the divide between art and industry, poetry and entertainment, “The Dark Knight” goes darker and deeper than any Hollywood movie of its comic-book kind.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Dark Knight

results.headline: The Pain Beneath the Pounds
results.summary_short: A struggling anorexic and her physical opposite form an unlikely friendship in “disFIGURED,” a funny, awkward and often uncomfortable drama.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Disfigured

results.headline: Plucky Apes Help to Save the Planet of the Humans
results.summary_short: Journalism is all about having the courage to write the truth even if it will get you mocked by your relatives and co-workers, so here goes: “Space Chimps” is hilarious.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Space Chimps

results.headline: Life Penalties
results.summary_short: If there is anything the cinema needed less than another angst-ridden, cross-cutting tragedy about crime, fate, memory and redemption, it’s the kind shot in an ugly monochromatic palette like “Take.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Take

results.headline: Firmly Planted
results.summary_short: Assembled without frills or fuss, “A Man Named Pearl” is as much a portrait of a small Southern town as of an unassuming black folk artist.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Man Named Pearl

results.headline: Crime and Journalism
results.summary_short: “A Very British Gangster” plays less like a documentary than an E! exposé of lowlife skulduggery.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Very British Gangster

results.headline: Opportunity Knocks
results.summary_short: “The Doorman,” a mockumentary about the people who run Manhattan nightlife, has solid-gold satire at its cocaine-stained fingertips.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Doorman

results.headline: Does Your Mother Know You Sing Abba Tunes?
results.summary_short: You can have a perfectly nice time watching this spirited adaptation of the popular stage musical and, once the hangover wears off, acknowledge just how bad it is.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mamma Mia!

results.headline: The Nightmare Disbelief of a Prisoner Under Siege
results.summary_short: Written and directed by Ric Roman Waugh, and filmed at the New Mexico State Penitentiary near Santa Fe, “Felon” is one of the most realistic prison films ever made.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Felon

results.headline: Hard Look at Tough Times for an Italian Marriage
results.summary_short: Silvio Soldini’s film “Days and Clouds” suggests that Italy’s middle class is as much under siege as that of the United States.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Days and Clouds

results.headline: A Tenacious Matriarch Who Won’t Go Quietly
results.summary_short: “The Stone Angel” is a film of tightly assembled bits and pieces that don’t fit comfortably together despite clever dashes of magical realism connecting past and present.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Stone Angel

results.headline: Lost, Lonely Souls Adrift, Randomly Crossing Paths
results.summary_short: “Garden Party” is a low-rent answer to Robert Altman’s “Short Cuts.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Garden Party
